alt: A picture of Andy being interviewed for a television segment.
description: The press often reports on my research, interviews me, or consults with me on my expertise
impacts: I consulted with APM's Marketplace Tech on automation (2019)
I wrote for the Huffington Post about the software industry's need for computing education research (2016).
LiveScience interviewed me about the efficacy of coding toys (2016).
NewScientist featured my work on Frictionary (2012)
IDG news featured our work Facebook's design culture (2012)
Seattle's King5 News interviewed me about software failures (2010)
PC Magazine featured my research on debugging tools (2005).
The Associated Press featured my research on the Whyline (2004).

alt: A photograph of the 2016 team at AnswerDash
description: My research often impacts policy and processes in software companies; I have also co-founded and consulted with startups
impacts: Our research on Lemonaid, our crowdsourced help tool, was the basis for AnswerDash, a company that I co-founded with Jacob Wobbrock and Parmit Chilana that offers an instant self-service answers product for web applications and e-commerce sites. The company has impacted other company's product offerings, including Zendesk's self-service technologies.
Our research on bug reporting has been read widely in industry, including by product teams at Microsoft, Adobe, Google, and ABB.

alt: A photograph of the 2010 Mozilla Summit
description: My research often reaches software developers through podcasts, news, and social media
impacts: I was interviewed for the Software Engineering Daily podcast, which has an audience of hundreds of thousands.
Our ACM Learning Webinar on software engineering expertise was viewed by hundreds of thousands of developers.

Our research on coding bootcamps has been read by hundreds of thousands of software developers on sites like <a href='https://www.reddit.com/r/programming/comments/6kgi7p/what_i_learned_from_researching_coding_bootcamps/'>Reddit and <a href='https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=14679061'>Hacker News<a/>.
Our work evaluating coding tutorials has been discussed on Hacker News.

alt: A screenshot of the Visual Studio IDE.
description: Many of my innovations have made it into software development tools products
impacts: Our studies on program understanding and ideas for program understanding tools was partially the basis of the Debugger Canvas plugin for Visual Studio.
Frictionary was used in one of the features in AnswerDash, the company I co-founded based on my CAREER grant
Timelapse is being upstreamed to WebKit and will likely appear in the Safari Web Inspector developer tools.
Many of the ideas in Barista have made it into more modern environments like Scratch and Greenfoot.

My research on the Whyline has impacted several projects, including Microsoft's IntelliTrace feature in Visual Studio, it's Debugger Canvas Visual Studio plugin, and the record-replay features in it's latest Chakra JavaScript runtime. Other projects, including Mozilla's rr and the Elm Debugger have also incorporated time-travel debugging features.

alt: A screenshot of Apple's Swift Playgrounds.
description: Many of my discoveries have impacted the design of educational technologies for learning to code
impacts: In 2016 I consulted with Microsoft on their MakeCode project, sharing evidence from computing education research to inform the design of their learning technologies.
Our work on Gidget influenced the design of Code.org's CodeStudio and Apple's Swift Playgrounds.

alt: A photograph of a CHI 2019 coffee break.
description: I share much of my experience, both of my research areas and of my practice as an scholars, in books, blog posts, podcasts, and other media
impacts: As part of my teaching, I enjoy writing short web accessible books that summarize the state of knowledge in my academic fields. I have written short books about Design, Cooperative Software Development, and User Interface Software and Technology. Many faculty at other universities have used my short books in their classes.
The Changing Academic Life podcast interviewed me about productivity.
My blog posts about academia and professor life are read by hundreds of thousands of academics.

alt: A photograph of my lab at SIGCSE 2019.
description: I actively seek ways to help build the computing education research community by improving or creating new infrastructure
impacts: I've consulted with Google, NSF, CRA, and Code.org about strategies for strengthening the pipeline of computing education research, researchers, and research funding.
I've co-authored a whitepaper discussing the importance of computing education research.
Since 2016 I've maintained a popular FAQ for newcomers to the community.

I've helped shape the peer review processes for the ACM Transactions on Computing Education, the ACM SIGCSE Technical Symposium's Research Track, and the ACM International Computing Education Research Conference.
My blog posts about computing education are read widely amongst researchers and CS teachers.

alt: A photograph of Andy at a national meeting of CS for All state advocates.
description: I've used my research and expertise to inform national policy and national curricula
impacts: I've coordinated with House representatives on policies that will expand the numbers of CS teachers nationwide.
Our research on programming problem solving and programming language learning has shaped Code.org's teacher professional development and it's secondary curricula.
Our research on software engineering expertise informed the curriculum at New York's Academy for Software Engineering.

alt: A photograph of an education committee meeting at the Washington state legislature.
description: I've used my research and expertise to inform Washington state policy on K-12 CS education
impacts: I direct CS for All Washington, a statewide CS for All advocacy group.
I've worked with leaders around Washington state to help it's colleges and universities to prepare K-12 CS teachers.
Our work on problem solving and program tracing has influenced the design of Code.org's curiculum and teacher professional development.

alt: A photograph a 2019 Sound CS Ed community meetup.
description: I've used my research and expertise to build community and educate youth in Puget Sound
impacts: I've run a quarterly meetup, Sound CS Ed, to bring together a community of hundreds of CS education teachers, researchers, policy makers, and product designers.

Since 2016 I've taught in the university's Upward Bound program, which primarily reaches low-income immigrant and refugee high school students in South Seattle. The students learn about computing, information, and design.
I have served on the Seattle Public Schools CS Advisory board, shaping strategic goals.
